bio: Gino D'Acampo - With over 25 years of experience, Gino D'Acampo is a popular Italian chef, restaurateur, and media personality. He has written numerous cookbooks and hosted several television shows, including Gino's Italian Escape.

cookingMethod: Cook spaghetti according to package directions.
Cook guanciale until crispy.
Whisk together egg yolks, Pecorino Romano cheese, and black pepper.
Toss cooked spaghetti with guanciale and egg mixture until coated.
Serve immediately.
Preheat oven to 475°F (245°C).
Stretch pizza dough to desired size and shape.
Spread tomato sauce over the dough.
Add slices of mozzarella cheese.
Sprinkle with torn basil leaves.
Drizzle with extra-virgin olive oil.
Bake for 10-15 minutes or until crust is golden brown.
Serve hot.
Mix egg yolks and sugar until creamy.
Add mascarpone cheese and mix until smooth.
Dip ladyfingers in espresso and arrange in a layer in a baking dish.
Cover with a layer of the mascarpone mixture.
Repeat with another layer of ladyfingers and mascarpone mixture.
Cover and chill for at least 2 hours.
Dust with cocoa powder before serving.

bio: Antonio Carluccio - Antonio Carluccio was an Italian chef, restaurateur, and author. He had over 50 years of experience and was known as the Godfather of Italian gastronomy. He authored over 20 books and hosted several TV shows, including Two Greedy Italians.

cookingMethod: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Cook lasagna noodles according to package directions.
In a large skillet, brown ground beef and Italian sausage with garlic and onion.
Add tomato sauce and simmer for 15-20 minutes.
In a mixing bowl, combine ricotta cheese, egg, and parmesan cheese.
In a 9x13 inch baking dish, layer lasagna noodles, meat sauce, and ricotta cheese mixture.
Top with mozzarella cheese.
Cover with foil and bake for 25 minutes.
Remove foil and bake for another 25 minutes or until cheese is golden brown.
Let rest for 10 minutes before serving.
Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Season chicken breasts with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and onion powder.
Coat chicken in flour, then beaten eggs, then breadcrumbs mixed with parmesan cheese.
Heat oil in a large skillet and cook chicken until golden brown on both sides.
Transfer chicken to a baking dish and top with marinara sauce and mozzarella cheese.
Bake for 10-15 minutes or until cheese is melted and bubbly.
Serve hot with additional marinara sauce if desired.
Cook pasta according to package directions.
In a food processor, pulse basil, pine nuts, garlic, and parmesan cheese until finely chopped.
With the food processor running, slowly drizzle in olive oil until a thick paste forms.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Toss cooked pasta with pesto until coated.
Serve hot or cold.

bio: Gennaro Contaldo - Gennaro Contaldo is a renowned Italian chef, restaurateur, and cookbook author with over 30 years of experience. He has worked with various famous chefs, including Jamie Oliver, and has authored several cookbooks.

cookingMethod: Cook spaghetti in salted boiling water until al dente.
In a large skillet, sauté pancetta and garlic over medium heat until crispy.
In a mixing bowl, whisk egg yolks, grated parmesan cheese, black pepper, and a pinch of salt.
Drain spaghetti and reserve 1/2 cup of pasta water.
Add spaghetti and pasta water to the skillet with pancetta and garlic, and toss until coated.
Remove skillet from heat and add egg mixture, stirring constantly until the sauce thickens.
Serve hot, garnished with additional parmesan cheese and black pepper.
Season veal shanks with salt and pepper, then coat with flour.
In a large skillet, brown veal shanks on all sides over medium-high heat.
Remove veal shanks and set aside.
In the same skillet, sauté carrots, celery, onion, and garlic until softened.
Add tomato paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add beef broth and white wine, stirring to scrape up any browned bits.
Add bay leaves, thyme, and rosemary.
Return veal shanks to the skillet and spoon some of the sauce over them.
Cover and simmer over low heat for 2-3 hours or until the meat is tender.
Serve hot, garnished with gremolata (a mixture of chopped parsley, lemon zest, and garlic).
In a mixing bowl, beat egg yolks and sugar until light and creamy.
Add mascarpone cheese and whisk until smooth.
In a separate bowl, combine espresso and Marsala wine.
Dip ladyfingers in the espresso mixture and arrange them in a single layer in a 9x13 inch dish.
Spread half of the mascarpone mixture over the ladyfingers.
Repeat with another layer of dipped ladyfingers and mascarpone mixture.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Before serving, dust with cocoa powder.

bio: Massimo Bottura - Massimo Bottura is a Michelin-starred Italian chef and restaurateur who has been named the best chef in the world several times. He has over 25 years of experience and is known for his innovative approach to traditional Italian cuisine.

cookingMethod: Slice tomatoes and fresh mozzarella cheese into even slices.
Arrange the tomato and mozzarella slices on a plate, alternating them.
Sprinkle salt and black pepper on top.
Drizzle extra-virgin olive oil and balsamic vinegar over the salad.
Garnish with fresh basil leaves.
Serve immediately.
Preheat the oven to 375°F.
Cook lasagna noodles according to package instructions.
In a large skillet, sauté ground beef, onion, and garlic until browned.
Add tomato sauce, tomato paste, and Italian seasoning, stirring to combine.
In a mixing bowl, combine ricotta cheese, grated parmesan cheese, salt, and black pepper.
Spread a thin layer of the meat sauce in the bottom of a 9x13 inch baking dish.
Add a layer of cooked lasagna noodles, overlapping slightly.
Spread a layer of the ricotta mixture over the noodles, then add another layer of the meat sauce.
Repeat with another layer of noodles, ricotta mixture, and meat sauce.
Top with shredded mozzarella cheese.
Cover with foil and bake for 25 minutes.
Remove foil and bake for an additional 25 minutes, or until cheese is melted and bubbly.
Let lasagna cool for 10-15 minutes before serving.
Preheat the oven to 375°F.
Pound chicken breasts to an even thickness.
Season chicken with salt and pepper.
Dredge chicken in flour, then dip in beaten egg, and coat with breadcrumbs.
In a large skillet, heat olive oil over medium-high heat.
Add chicken breasts and cook until golden brown on both sides.
Transfer chicken to a baking dish.
Top each chicken breast with tomato sauce, mozzarella cheese, and grated parmesan cheese.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until chicken is cooked through and cheese is melted and bubbly.
Let chicken cool for 5 minutes before serving.

bio: Lidia Bastianich - Lidia Bastianich is an Italian-American chef, restaurateur, and cookbook author with over 50 years of experience. She has hosted several television shows and written numerous cookbooks, including Lidia's Italy.

cookingMethod: Cook spaghetti in a large pot of boiling salted water according to package instructions.
While the spaghetti cooks, fry the bacon in a skillet over medium heat until crisp.
In a mixing bowl, whisk together egg yolks, grated parmesan cheese, salt, and black pepper.
Drain the cooked spaghetti and add it to the skillet with the bacon, tossing to combine.
Remove the skillet from the heat and add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to coat the spaghetti.
The residual heat will cook the egg yolks and create a creamy sauce.
Serve immediately, topped with additional parmesan cheese and black pepper if desired.
Preheat the oven to 450°F.
Roll out the pizza dough into a 12-inch circle.
Spread a thin layer of extra-virgin olive oil over the dough, leaving a 1/2-inch border.
Slice the tomatoes and fresh mozzarella cheese into even slices.
Arrange the tomato and mozzarella slices on top of the pizza dough, leaving a 1/2-inch border.
Sprinkle salt over the tomatoes and mozzarella.
Bake the pizza for 12-15 minutes, or until the crust is golden brown and the cheese is melted and bubbly.
Remove the pizza from the oven and let it cool for a few minutes.
Garnish with fresh basil leaves, then slice and serve.
Brew espresso and stir in Marsala wine.
In a mixing bowl, whisk together egg yolks and sugar until light and fluffy.
Add mascarpone cheese to the egg yolk mixture, whisking until smooth.
Dip ladyfingers in the espresso mixture and arrange them in a single layer in a 9x13 inch baking dish.
Spread half of the mascarpone mixture over the ladyfingers.
Repeat with another layer of espresso-dipped ladyfingers and mascarpone mixture.
Cover with plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours, or overnight.
Before serving, dust the top with cocoa powder.
Slice and serve.

bio: Giada De Laurentiis - Giada De Laurentiis is an Italian-American chef, author, and television personality. She has over 20 years of experience and has hosted several popular shows, including Giada at Home and Giada Entertains. She has authored several cookbooks and is known for her simple, Italian-inspired recipes.

cookingMethod: Heat the beef broth in a saucepan and keep it simmering.
Melt the butter in a large saucepan over medium heat.
Add the finely chopped onion and cook until it softens and turns translucent.
Add the rice to the onion and stir until all grains are coated with butter.
Add a splash of white wine to the rice and stir until the wine is absorbed.
Add a ladleful of beef broth to the rice and stir until the broth is absorbed.
Repeat this process, adding a ladleful of broth at a time, stirring continuously and waiting for each addition to be absorbed before adding the next.
After about 15-18 minutes of cooking, the rice should be al dente.
Stir in the saffron and grated Parmesan cheese.
Remove from heat and let the risotto rest for a few minutes before serving.
In a food processor, pulse together the basil leaves, garlic, and pine nuts until finely chopped.
Add grated Parmesan cheese and pulse a few times more.
With the food processor running, slowly pour in the extra-virgin olive oil until the pesto is smooth and creamy.
Season with salt to taste.
Serve with pasta, bread, or as a condiment for meat or fish.
Season the veal shanks with salt and pepper, then dredge them in flour.
Heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium heat.
Brown the veal shanks on all sides, then remove them from the pot.
In the same pot, add chopped onion, celery, and carrots, and sauté until they soften.
Add minced garlic and tomato paste, and cook for a minute or two.
Deglaze the pot with white wine, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom.
Add beef broth to the pot and stir to combine.
Return the veal shanks to the pot, making sure they are covered with the sauce.
Simmer the osso buco over low heat for 2-3 hours, or until the meat is tender and falls off the bone.
Before serving, garnish with chopped parsley and lemon zest.
